title: 103_hr1253
content: The Legislative Line Item Veto Act of 1993 allows for legislative line item veto rescission authority. The President can rescind discretionary budget authority under certain conditions to reduce the Federal budget deficit, without impairing essential Government functions or harming the national interest. The notification to Congress must be done within twenty calendar days after the enactment of an appropriation Act. The President can rescind discretionary budget authority to reduce the Federal budget deficit without harming essential Government functions or the national interest. A separate rescission message must be submitted for each item rescinded. SEC. 3. RESCISSION EFFECTIVE UNLESS DISAPPROVED. Any budget authority rescinded under this Act by the President will be canceled unless a rescission disapproval bill is enacted into law within a specified timeframe. This includes a 20-day congressional review period, followed by an additional ten days for the President to sign or veto the bill, and an extra five days if the President vetoes the bill. During the period specified, an additional five calendar days of session are allowed after a veto. If a special message is sent by the President and Congress adjourns before the review period ends, the rescission will not take effect. The message is considered retransmitted at the start of the next Congress. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "rescission disapproval bill" refers to a bill or joint resolution disapproving a rescission of discretionary budget authority. The term "calendar days of session" means only days when both Houses of Congress are in session. The President must send a special message to Congress when rescinding budget authority, detailing the amount, where it was allocated, reasons for the rescission, and its fiscal impact. The President must send a special message to Congress when rescinding budget authority, detailing the amount, allocation, reasons, and fiscal impact. The special message must be transmitted to the House and Senate on the same day, referred to the appropriate committees, and printed in the Federal Register. The rescission disapproval bill introduced with respect to a special message shall be referred to the appropriate committees of the House of Representatives or the Senate. Any rescission disapproval bill received in the Senate from the House shall be considered in the Senate with debate limited to ten hours. Debate in the Senate on debatable motions or appeals regarding a bill is limited to one hour, divided between the mover and the bill manager. The minority leader can control time in opposition. Additional time can be allotted by the leaders. A motion to further limit debate is not debatable, and a motion to recommit is not in order. In the Senate or House of Representatives, it is not allowed to consider any rescission disapproval bill that does not relate to the budget authority transmitted by the President. Amendments to a rescission disapproval bill are also not permitted. These restrictions can be waived in the Senate with a three-fifths majority vote.
